DOC.HEAD: Cold Wave Means Good Waves
With AM-Cold Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The temperature was only 40 and the wind was blowing, but Sunday's record cold was accompanied by good waves that attracted die-hard surfers. ``It's not often to find waves that big,'' said Paul Meccariello, 27. ``It's something to do with the weather. Usually the big waves are blocked by the Bahamas Islands.'' More than 50 surfers clad in insulating wetsuits gathered in the 67-degree water waiting for good waves. Earlier in the day, Miami had cooled to a record low of just 31 degrees. Meccariello couldn't estimate how high the waves were. There were swells that appeared several feet high in a small area. He had called a recorded surf report from his home in Hollywood, Fla. ``They said this was the spot to be. This is where they're breaking,'' he said. ``I guess they all called there, too,'' he said of the other surfers. In spite of the good surf, Ben Alloche, 17, was going home. ``It's too crowded,'' he said. It was too cold to work on a tan, so tourists with coats buttoned and hands thrust into their pockets watched the surfers from the beach. Marcus Lemmler, 23, arrived Thursday from Switzerland, which he said has had record high temperatures. ``There's no snow in Switzerland, so we came to Miami to find it,'' he laughed.
